At-a-Glance: Track jars and batches from tank to customer. Simple codes and par levels prevent stockouts and chaos.
Why it Matters: Saves time at markets and online packing.
Objectives: Adopt a single batch code format across all SKUs.
Set par levels per channel and plan replenishment.
Record moves between stores, vans, and stockists.
What Good Looks Like: Master sheet: batch → SKU → quantity → location.
Reorder triggers by week and event calendar.
Step-by-Step: 1) Define batch code and label position.
2) Record jarring counts to master; split to channels.
3) At pick: scan/mark; at return: reconcile and adjust.
4) Review weekly; book next jarring run.
Seasonality & Climate: Pre-Christmas par levels higher; heat affects wax/candles storage.
Data & Thresholds: Par levels by SKU/channel; reorder lead time noted.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Issue: Stockouts -> Raise par; shorten lead times; batch more frequently.
Issue: Lost batch trace -> Fix label position and scanning habit.
Issue: Overstock -> Bundle or sample near end of season.
Common Pitfalls: Counting in vans but not reconciling.
No separation of wholesale cases vs singles.
Tools & Techniques: Shared spreadsheet or light inventory app; QR/barcodes optional.
Pick tickets for markets and wholesale orders.
Safety & Compliance: Secure food storage away from chemicals and pets.
Communications: Teach volunteers where to find batch codes fast.
Notes: Use the same batch on matching gift packs to simplify traceability.
